climbs.name: Tall Talking Midget
climbs.fa: Bob D'Antonio, Vaino Kodas and Moe Hershoff

content.description: This is a great little route that packs a lot punch in short distance, hence the name. On the right side of the cliff, just right of a hanging arete is a line of bolts up a very steep wall. Stick-clip the first bolts and make a series of hard finger jams up to a solid handjam. Clip the second bolt and lay-back up a shallow seam, past the 3rd and 4th bolts to a semi-good-rest. Clip the 5th bolt and crank up to the  anchor. Excellent and pumpy climbing for such a short route.
content.protection: Five bolts lead to a two-bolt anchor.

content.description: This is a crack that starts finger-sized and gradually gets larger until it is an offwidth crack.  It is hand-sized at the top.  It is fairly consistent in difficulty along its length.  There is no specific crux section.  It is the best climb I have done on this wall.
content.protection: Standard rack up to a #5 Camalot.  Two #4s are useful.  Build a gear anchor at the top.
content.location:
This is the wide crack between

Tall Talking Midget

and

Lion's Den

. It is in a left-facing dihedral.  You walk off to the left or right.

content.description: This route starts in the dihedral with a very small crack.  There is some rotten rock here, and there is lots of lichen up high with rock that looks poorly attached.  You have to stem a lot to get up this route, and it felt difficult for 10b.  It felt about 10d 3/4s of the way up as you stem with poor handholds.
content.location:
This is the dirty, left-facing dihedral in the center of the wall to the left of

Tall Talking Midget

.  You get down by walking to the left or right.

content.description: This route is graded 5.9 in D'Antonio's guide and by Rossiter's too, but I thought it was a little harder, maybe 10a.  The crack is fairly large for hand jams (Rossiter does call it a fist crack) except in the back of it if you reach way far in.  There are face holds in a few spots but not many.  This is good because using just the crack would be very difficult.  The route protects well yet it was a shock to find something harder than 5.9.  Maybe I was just having an off day.
content.protection: Double #1 to #4 Camalots and a standard rack for an anchor.
content.location: This route is to the right of Skin and Bones and two routes to the right of Tall Talking Midget.  It is the furthest right route at the crag. There is a rock slab at the bottom and this is the obvious hand crack. Descend by walking down the gully to the right.

content.description: This is a slightly overhanging hand and finger crack.  The crux is at the top near the end.  Like other routes at this crag, it felt harder than the rating in the D'Antonio guidebook.  The exit moves felt about 10d-11a with a poor handcrack.  The crack below the top is fun.  The slight overhanging nature of the route increases its difficulty.
content.protection: Standard rack to a #3 Camalot.  Build a gear anchor at the top.
content.location: This is the furthest left route on the wall and it is just to the right of a large overhang.  Walk off to the right or left.
